item.title: [WebCryptoAPI] variable's value not immediately obvious without looking at linked code sample
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto/decrypt

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SubtleCrypto/decrypt#aes-cbc

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The code snippet provided does not make it immediately obvious where the variable iv comes from.

What did you expect to see?

Reading the code sample linked in the description Does give enough context to figure this out.

Expected:

iv = window.crypto.getRandomValues(new Uint8Array(16));

Context

However, upon rereading encrypt function I noticed the comment
// iv will be needed for decryption
which then made sense.

Solution:

Since the code snippets look to be copy pasted from the code sample, adding a comment to the decrypt function similar to encrypt function would help make it obvious what the expected value of the variable iv should be.

such as:
// iv used during encryption

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] The description of the parameter "key" of IDBObjectStore.put() looks false
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/put

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Parameters

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The current descriotion of the parameter key says:

This is only needed for object stores that have an autoIncrement primary key, therefore the key is not in a field on the record object. In such cases, calling put(item) will always insert a new record, because it doesn't know what existing record you might want to modify.

What did you expect to see?

The "Exceptions" sections says that DataError will be thrown when:

  • The object store uses in-line keys or has a key generator, and a key parameter was provided.
  • The object store uses out-of-line keys and has no key generator, and no key parameter was provided.

Therefore, specifying the key parameter for object stores that have an autoIncrement primary key (key generator) should result in an exception and records shouldn't be inserted nor updated.

Also, the key parameter is required for object stores using out-of-line keys to avoid exceptions, so the "only needed" part looks false.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

MDN metadata

Page report details
  • Folder: en-us/web/api/idbobjectstore/put
  • MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBObjectStore/put

item.title: [audio-output] [Web API] enable Audio Output Devices API on nightly
item.content:encoded:
Acceptance Criteria

  • The listed features are documented sufficiently on MDN
  • BCD is updated
  • Interactive example and data repos are updated if appropriate
  • The content has been reviewed as needed

For folks helping with Firefox related documentation

  • Set bugs to dev-doc-complete
  • Add entry to Firefox release notes if feature is enabled in release
  • Add entry to Firefox experimental features page if feature is not yet enabled in release

Features to document

https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-output/

Looks like we have both additions:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLMediaElement/setSinkId
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaDevices/selectAudioOutput

We should probably have an API overview page for it, but due to the size of this months project we may not have time.

Related Gecko bugs

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1794961

Other

  • Check content open issues to see if any pertain to the subject matter. If there are any that can be closed because of the work, do so. If there are any that can be fixed relatively quickly because of the knowledge from completing this issue and you have time, feel free to go ahead and fix them.
  • Check if glossary updates are required for the feature you're documenting - whether an existing term needs to be updated or a new term should be added.
  • Check if BCD update means that content pages need to have experimental markup removed or deprecated markup added (front matter tags and macros).

item.title: [html, CSP3] Clarify the sandbox directive use in Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Directives

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Hi,

In Sandox directive description https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy/sandbox :
"This directive is not supported in the element or by the Content-Security-policy-Report-Only header field."

I understand that you can't use sandbox in Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only because it is not supported.

But in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only :
"The directives of the Content-Security-Policy header can also be applied to Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only."

This is not entirely true because sandbox is said to be unsupported in Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only header.

What did you expect to see?

If sandbox is really unsupported or it is not used in Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only ,
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only should say something like
"The directives of the Content-Security-Policy header can also be applied to Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only except for sandbox directive which is unsupported in Content-Security-Policy."

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

item.title: [selectors-4] inaccurate example on the :not() page
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/:not

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Description

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

last bullet:

If any selector passed to the :not() pseudo-class is invalid or not supported by the browser, the whole rule will be invalidated. The effective way to overcome this behavior is to use :is pseudo-class, which accepts a forgiving selector list. For example :not(.foo, :invalid-pseudo-class) will invalidate a whole rule, but :is(:not(.foo), :not(:invalid-pseudo-class)) will match any element that isn't .foo.

What did you expect to see?

the example is inaccurate, as :not(.foo, :invalid-pseudo-class) matches NEITHER .foo NOR :invalid-pseudo-class
whereas :is(:not(.foo), :not(:invalid-pseudo-class)) matches anything that simply isn't .foo (disregarding the second condition)
it will also match elements that weren't intended to initially, thus isn't a very good example of overcoming the issue.. :)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

made a pen example

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [webaudio] Visualization is by far not the only use case for FFT
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AnalyserNode/frequencyBinCount

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Intro

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

aawerrawrawe

What did you expect to see?

awereawrrawe

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

In the following statement:

This generally equates to the number of data values you will have to play with for the visualization.

The part in italics mentions just one very specific use case for FFT, but makes it sound as if this were the only use-case for FFT. It also sounds slightly colloquial ("play with"). It is also very inaccurate, for example it doesn't mention the linear relationship between array index and frequency, which is not necessarily expected (it could just as well be logarithmic to the casual observer).

Proposed wording:

This is the total number of data points available. Their indices have a linear relationship with the frequencies they represent, between 0 and the Nyquist frequency (half the audio context's sampleRate).

item.content:encoded:

CSS property values may be accessed using the getPropertyValue(propName) API or by indexing directly into the object such as obj['z-index'] or obj.zIndex.

let availableProps = getComputedStyle(document.body);

item.title: [SVG11] Inconsistency with experimental status of textPath attribute method
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Element/textPath

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

attribute method

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There is an inconsistency with the experimental status of the attribute "method" compared to the documentation at https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/method. This web page does not describe it as experimental while the latter one does. It is defined in both SVG 1.1 and SVG 2.0, so it would not seem to be experimental. However, when I tested it on a cursive font (Dancing Script) where the attribute should matter most, it did not look any different in Chrome or Firefox. So either my test was not appropriate or the attribute is not supported despite the documentation. A sample SVG snippet is below. It shows the two possible "method" values of "align" and "stretch" being used. The text of both is overlaid, and as can be seen, the glyphs match up perfectly. In the preview, it mostly is removed, but it was added again in a later section.

<!-- Testing attribute method with cursive Google font -->
<svg width="1250" height="650">
  <title>Text following a path using textPath testing attribute "method".</title>
  <defs>
    <style type="text/css">@import
        url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Dancing+Script');
    </style>
    <path id="method-test-path"
        d="M70 500 C 100 0, 200 0, 400 400 S 800 500, 1200 40"
        style="stroke: gray; fill: none;"/>
  </defs>

  <use xlink:href="#method-test-path"/>

  <text style="font-size: 72; font-family: Dancing Script">
    <textPath xlink:href="#method-test-path" method="align">
        An example that tests the "method" attribute with value of "align".
    </textPath>
  </text>

  <text style="font-size: 72; font-family: Dancing Script">
    <textPath xlink:href="#method-test-path" method="stretch">
        An example that tests the "method" attribute with value of "stretch".
    </textPath>
  </text>
  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="none"
      stroke="#000" stroke-opacity="0.5" />
</svg>

What did you expect to see?

There should have been changes to the glyphs when the "stretch" option was used with larger differences where the path was more curved.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/text.html#TextPathElementMethodAttribute
https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/text.html#TextPathElementMethodAttribute
https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Dancing+Script

Do you have anything more you want to share?

The SVG below is the same as given earlier

<!-- Testing attribute method with cursive Google font -->
<svg width="1250" height="650">
  <title>Text following a path using textPath testing attribute "method".</title>
  <defs>
    <style type="text/css">@import
        url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Dancing+Script');
    </style>
    <path id="method-test-path"
        d="M70 500 C 100 0, 200 0, 400 400 S 800 500, 1200 40"
        style="stroke: gray; fill: none;"/>
  </defs>

  <use xlink:href="#method-test-path"/>

  <text style="font-size: 72; font-family: Dancing Script">
    <textPath xlink:href="#method-test-path" method="align">
        An example that tests the "method" attribute with value of "align".
    </textPath>
  </text>

  <text style="font-size: 72; font-family: Dancing Script">
    <textPath xlink:href="#method-test-path" method="stretch">
        An example that tests the "method" attribute with value of "stretch".
    </textPath>
  </text>
  <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="none"
      stroke="#000" stroke-opacity="0.5" />
</svg>

item.title: [webrtc] What is `RTCPeerConnection.generateCertificate(..)` good for?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/RTCPeerConnection/generateCertificate

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I think i want to use RTCPeerConnection.generateCertificate() for something? but i'm not really sure what it's really good for...
It says you can store the certificate in IndexedDB.

But why do you want to generate your own certificate and store it in IndexedDB instead of generating a new one each time?

Can the SDP offer/answer be more deterministic so that you can re-establish a closed RTCPeerConnection without having to send the signal back and forth after a connection is closed?

Would it be a huge benefit if i needed to connect to many peers and create some kind of mesh network and used the same certificate where many peers joins/leaves all the time?

What did you expect to see?

More/better use cases of why you want to use this. and how to use it.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

No response

item.title: [web-animations-2] "Automatically removing filling animations" and several related docs are incorrect and/or extremely confusing
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Animation#automatically_removing_filling_animations

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Automatically removing filling animations

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

  • Page says "remove" event is fired when animation is put into "active" replace state, but actually after a "remove" event the replace state must be "removed", and "active" is the initial/default state
  • Animation.replaceState page says that "removed" is for when an animation is "explicitly removed", but it's not clear if or how that's possible.
  • The example doesn't actually demonstrate all of the things it claims (for example, it does not print the replace state at any relevant point).
  • Animation.commitStyles() and the aforementioned example claim that the end state is written, but spec says the current state is written; see also #20086
  • probably more things

What did you expect to see?

Clear docs with supporting examples, terminology used in a manner consist with its meaning in the spec?

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

See links above.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

I'm not exactly a subject matter expert here, I might be (am) very confused.

item.title: [css-shadow-parts-1] ::part(): Missing information
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/::part

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

all of it

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

there are tons of limits on using ::part(), not of which are described.

What did you expect to see?

Selecting a Shadow Element: the ::part() pseudo-element

The ::part() pseudo-element allows you to select elements that have been exposed via a part attribute. The syntax is:

::part() = ::part( + )

The ::part() pseudo-element only matches anything when the originating element is a shadow host. If the originating elements shadow roots part element map contains all of the specified s, ::part() matches the element or elements keyed to that . Otherwise, it matches nothing.
For example, if you have a custom button that contains a "label" element that is exposed for styling (via part="label"), you can select it with #the-button::part(label).
Part names act similarly to classes: multiple elements can have the same part name, and a single element can have multiple part names.

A tabstrip control might have multiple elements with part="tab", all of which are selected by ::part(tab).

If a single tab is active at a time, it can be specially indicated with part="tab active" and then selected by ::part(tab active) (or ::part(active tab), as order doesnt matter).

The ::part() pseudo-element can take additional pseudo-classes after it, such as x-button::part(label):hover, but never matches the structural pseudo-classes or any other pseudo-classes that match based on tree information rather than local element information.

The ::part() pseudo-element can also take additional pseudo-elements after it, such as x-button::part(label)::before, but never match additional ::part()s.
For example, x-panel::part(confirm-button)::part(label) never matches anything. This is because doing so would expose more structural information than is intended.

If the s internal confirm button had used something like part="label => confirm-label" to forward the buttons internal parts up into the panels own part element map, then a selector like x-panel::part(confirm-label) would select just the one buttons label, ignoring any other labels.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://w3c.github.io/csswg-drafts/css-shadow-parts/#part

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [html, dom, css-backgrounds-4] Duplicate content inside the JavaScript events page
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events#a_simple_example

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The explanation of addEventListener() method is being repeated on different sections on the same page.

There is a section titled "A simple example" that has the following content:

const btn = document.querySelector('button');

function random(number) {
  return Math.floor(Math.random() * (number+1));
}

btn.addEventListener('click', () => {
  const rndCol = `rgb(${random(255)}, ${random(255)}, ${random(255)})`;
  document.body.style.backgroundColor = rndCol;
});

Objects that can fire events have an addEventListener() method, that takes at least two arguments: the name of the event and a function to handle the event. So we call the button's addEventListener() method, passing in:

  • the string 'click', to indicate that we want to listen to the click event

  • a function to call when the event happens. In our case, the function generates a random RGB color and sets the page background-color equal to that color.

Another section titled "Using addEventListener()" has almost the same content:

const btn = document.querySelector('button');

function random(number) {
  return Math.floor(Math.random() * (number+1));
}

btn.addEventListener('click', () => {
  const rndCol = `rgb(${random(255)}, ${random(255)}, ${random(255)})`;
  document.body.style.backgroundColor = rndCol;
});

Inside the addEventListener() function, we specify two parameters: the name of the event we want to register this handler for, and the code that comprises the handler function we want to run in response to it.

What did you expect to see?

The "Using addEventListener()" section begins with an explanation of the addEventListener() method and an explanation on how to use a separate named function for handling the event instead of using an anonymous function.

I would suggest removing the duplicate content inside the "Using addEventListener()" section and replacing it with something like this:

We've already seen how to handle a click event by using an anonymous function from the previous example. But
we could also use a separate named function to handle the same event, like so:

const btn = document.querySelector('button');

function random(number) {
  return Math.floor(Math.random() * (number+1));
}

function changeBackground() {
  const rndCol = `rgb(${random(255)}, ${random(255)}, ${random(255)})`;
  document.body.style.backgroundColor = rndCol;
}

btn.addEventListener('click', changeBackground);

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

item.title: [orientation-event] Explanation of X, y, z coordinates of DeviceMotionEvent.acceleration and DeviceMotionEvent.accelerationIncludingGravity is either completely wrong or extremely confusing (or both)
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DeviceMotionEvent/acceleration

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It says:

x
Represents the acceleration upon the x axis which is the west to east axis
y
Represents the acceleration upon the y axis which is the south to north axis

z
Represents the acceleration upon the z axis which is the down to up axis

Now, the definitions of "west to east" and "south to north" axes are completely unambiguous (unless you are on one of the poles), and crystal clear. And it's definitely not true that x and y correspond to west to east and north to south.

"Down to up" on its own would be potentially ambiguous, but given the other two are east to west and south to north, one can only reasonably assume that "up to down" is referring to the surface of the earth. And of course, that is also not true.

By that description, one would unambiguously understand (wrongly) that the coordinates are absolute and in no way influenced by the orientation of the device. One can only infer that the system has already done the necessary calculations behind the scene to compute those values (which by the way is only possible by using also the compass as well as the accelerometer; and also I think it would involve some heuristics, not entirely sure about that).

I couldn't believe it but it is so crystal clear and unambiguously stated, that I assumed it had to be true. But of course my gut instinct was right

What did you expect to see?

From some quick experiments, I think the reality is:

x: corresponds to the x axis of the html document (not sure if with the same sign or opposite)
y: corresponds to the y axis of the html document (not sure if with the same sign or opposite)
z: corresponds to the remaining perpendicular axis, so one that either points into the screen or out of the screen.

Which of course makes way more sense

And this is true both for acceleration and accelerationIncludingGravity

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

No response

item.title: [css-fonts-5] getComputedStyle() does not respect the Fallback weights algorithm
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-weight

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There is missing information that getComputedStyle() on an element with a weight style which the font does not support actually does not return the real shown font weight but the weight style number thus not reflecting the result of the Fallback weights algorithm.

What did you expect to see?

A warning that getComputedStyle() has unintuitive behavior regarding font weight (especially surprising when one uses a variable font which supports "infinite" range of weights like Inter).

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Hacky test code changing font weight based on font size:

  function f( e, x ){
    return Math.trunc( parseInt( window.getComputedStyle( e )['font-weight'], 10 ) *
        // 14 font size => 1.005 font weight coefficient, 32 => 1.11, ...
        ( (Math.abs(x -14) * (1.11 -1.005)/(32 -14) ) +1.005 ) )
  }
  for( const e of document.querySelectorAll( '*, *::after, *::before, *::first-letter, *::first-line, *::selection, *::backdrop' ).values() ){
    try {
      const x = parseFloat( window.getComputedStyle( e )['font-size'] )
      const y = f( e, x )
      e.style.setProperty( 'font-weight',  y, 'important' )
      // not a variable font (or one which does not support fine-grained weight settings)
      // does not work as of 20221123_124058+0100 in newest Chromium
      //if( f() !== y ){
        e.style.setProperty( 'font-family', 'Inter var', 'important' )
      //}
    } catch {}
  }
@font-face {
  font-family: 'Inter var';
  font-style: oblique 0deg 10deg;
  font-weight: 100 900;
  font-display: swap;
  src: url( 'https://rsms.me/font-files/Inter.var.woff2?v=3.19' ) format( 'woff2' );
  font-feature-settings: "zero" 1, "ss01" 1;
}

item.title: [html, uievents] Document.activeElement : The lack of HTMLAnchorElement and macOS on a case by case basis
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/API/Document/activeElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Document.activeElement

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Hello,

The introduction of the article (and the entire content) is totally focused on input elements.

The most common cases

Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object.

However, in the major operating systems (OS) and browsers (I tested only on 4), the HTMLAnchorElement (A element) is focusable.

In the era of accessibility, for those who navigate with the keyboard, and for all those (everybody) who click on a link (A or an internal anchor #) : the focus is triggered and the Document.activeElement returns anHTMLAnchorElement.

And there are often more links (A links) in a page than input elements. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This can be confusing, when you see yourself that the majority of the elements not mentioned in the article take the focus by default, in general.

The case of macOS

There is an exception on macOS (which is specified in the article), but by looking for information about Document.activeContent, it seems to me that more explanations can be provided.

Which elements are focusable varies depending on the platform and the browser's current configuration. For example, on macOS systems, elements that aren't text input elements are not typically focusable by default.

This is true, but a clarification can be added : on macOS only some browsers take into account the default configuration of the operating system : Safari and Chrome do, but Firefox and Microsoft Edge do not. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This last information can be confusing when looing for information about Document.activeElement. Indeed, with the default macOS configuration, if when testing on Chome the A elements are not focusable but when testing on Firefox they are, the article does not really open your eyes to the macOS configuration (which is not taken into account by at least half of the browsers).

What did you expect to see?

It can be expected the HTMLAnchorElement to be referenced as a focusable element.
Alternatively, the sentence the "Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object" could be modified to explain the context of this specification. The writer(s) are probably thinking of the use of Document.activeElement in the listener of a FocusEvent whose target would be a HTMLInputElement or a HTMLTextareaElement, but as a developer it is interesting to have a more global view.

Of course, the precision regarding macOS should be retained, but perhaps adding that "some elements are not typically focusable by default" is also browser dependent on macOS (regardeless the configuration). This could avoid extensive research into why it works on one browser but not the other.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

For example, on the page Document.activeElement, by counting focusable elements.

Most common cases

The HTMLAnchorElement are focusable on Linux, on Windows and on macOS (with the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls"), and it seems that this is for all browsers :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox/Edge/Chrome/Safari 215 15 1

The case of macOS

On macOS, with default OS configuration (without the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls" so) :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox 215 15 1
Microsoft Edge 215 15 1
Chome 0 15 1
Safari 0 0 1

item.title: [css-logical-1] The article on the CSS float property lists several non-standard values as supported, with no explanation of what they are or where they came from
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/float

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Formal syntax

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The list of valid values for floats includes several values that were never formally adopted into any standards -- specifically, values from the CSS Page Floats draft, last updated in 2015, which isn't linked to or mentioned in the float article.

The following values from that standard are listed in this section but do not work in Firefox or, presumably, any modern browser:

  • top
  • bottom
  • block-start
  • block-end
  • snap-block(...)
  • snap-inline(...)
  • footnote

The following values from the draft standard work in Firefox, but not Chrome or Edge. They are listed on the page with no mention that they're part of the draft standard, and they're not listed in the CSS 2 standard linked to by the page.

  • inline-start
  • inline-end

The browser support section mentions inline-start and inline-end, but not the others, and not the draft standard in general.

What did you expect to see?

Only values that are standardized should be listed.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

CSS Page Floats draft standard defines the values I'm referring to.

CSS 2 float values as linked from the article: no mention of the values I'm referring to.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [file-system-access] File System Access API is incomplete
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileSystemHandle

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

FileSystemDirectoryHandle

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The File System Access API doesn't address the question of how to manage package bundles (e.g. .textbundle files) or compressed archives (e.g. .zip files).

The above types of files have a kind of 'file' when they should really be identified as having a kind of 'Directory'.

You cannot use window.showDirectoryPicker() to select a package bundle or zip archive.

The window.showOpenFilePicker() allows us to select the above types of files, but won't allow us to work with their contents.

What did you expect to see?

Package bundles or compressed archives should really be identified as having a kind of 'Directory' and be accessible using the window.showDirectoryPicker() method.

We should be able to identify and iterate through the contents of such packages.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://playcode.io/1000385

item.title: [picture-in-picture] Clarify/note Document.pictureInPictureElement is null for PiP launched from iframe
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/pictureInPictureElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Clarify Document.pictureInPictureElement is null for iframe with different origin than the parent document.

What did you expect to see?

Note or explanation that Document.pictureInPictureElement is null for iframe with different origin than the parent document.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

4.3. Extension to DocumentOrShadowRoot

partial interface mixin [DocumentOrShadowRoot](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#documentorshadowroot) {
  readonly attribute [Element](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#element)? pictureInPictureElement;
};

The pictureInPictureElement attributes getter must run these steps:

If the context object is not [connected](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#connected), return null and abort these steps.

Let candidate be the result of [retargeting](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#retarget) Picture-in-Picture element against the context object.

If candidate and the context object are in the same [tree](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-tree), return candidate and abort these steps.

Return null.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Steps to reproduce (where W3C Picture-in-Picture specification is supported):

  1. Append an iframe with src to an origin other than parent document's containing a media element that autoplays and is in auto picture in picture mode;
  2. When Picture-in-Picture loads call document.pictureInPictureElement; observe return value is null

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] indexedDB.deleteDatabase doc: Mention that deleting a database isn't completed until the upgradeNeeded result is closed
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBFactory/deleteDatabase

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When calling IDBFactory.deleteDatabase(), the database isn't deleted until the upgradeneeded event is garbage collected, which can by triggered by calling request.result.close() on the indexedDB.open() result.

What did you expect to see?

Mention that onsuccess won't be fired until the indexedDB.open() result is closed like so:

const request = indexedDB.open(dbName);
request.onupgradeneeded = () => {
  request.result.close();
}

though to be honest I'm not sure how much of this depends on my specific situation. I reckon there might be other calls that similarly cause a database to stay open like this.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Initially I thought this was a bug in Chrome, so I reported https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1359843. But it seems like this behaviour is intentional.
You can find an example of this behaviour at https://indexeddb-deletedatabase-hanging.glitch.me/
you'll see that unless you have the 'close indexedDB.open() result' checkbox checked, deleting databases will take significantly longer depending on how fast the objects are garbage collected.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [mediastream-recording] Emitted blobs do not always exactly adhere to the timeslice value
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaRecorder/dataavailable_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

First section, fourth bullet point about the timeslice parameter

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The documentation currently says this:

If a timeslice property was passed into the MediaRecorder.start() method that started media capture, a dataavailable event is fired every timeslice milliseconds.

However, I used to record videos with a MediaRecorder like this (in vuejs):

startRecording: function () {
    this.recorder = new MediaRecorder(this.streamSrc, {mimeType: "video/webm;codecs:vp8"});
    this.recorder.ondataavailable = this.onData;
    this.recorder.start(500);
},
onData: function (event) {
    // append the latest chunk of video data to an array
    this.chunks.push(event.data);
    this.duration = this.chunks.length * 500 / 1000;
}

and expected each blob emitted to the onData handler to contain exactly 500 ms of video. Hence, I simply used the length of the array to show the total recorded video duration to the user.

As it turns out, the computed duration would accumulate a substantial drift from the real duration as the video got longer. After around 10 minutes of video, the displayed duration value would differ from the actual video duration by multiple seconds.
I ended up implementing my own "stopwatch" to keep track of the recorded duration, which works much more accurately.

From my understanding of how video codecs work, I imagine it's hard to make a sensible "cut" precisely after a given timeslice value and that's perhaps why we cannot rely on emitted blobs to have exactly the specified duration.

What did you expect to see?

If my usage of the timeslice option and the assumption about video codecs is correct, I would suggest to adapt the documentation in a way to reflect this.

From reading the current description, I thought the blob duration was reliable and had to spend effort debugging it when it wasn't.

item.title: [cssom-view-1] False claim: window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/scrollY

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Notes

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The pageYOffset property is an alias for the scrollY property:

window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true

What did you expect to see?

If not redefined, the scrollY property is an alias for the pageYOffset property. In that case following holds:

window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY; // always true

(I do not know if this makes any sense. See supporting information.)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I created some content-scripts on Google Chrome (through Extension) which sets the property window.scrollYto a negative value (which actually was a bug of my content script, but nevertheless it exposed this problem here).

Afterwards window.pageYOffset === window.scrollY was no more true on the content-script,as window.scrollY stayed negative, but window.pageYOffset continued to work as usual.

Also you state, this property is readonly. Whatever this means, because I thought that by assigning to window.scrollY you can create an effect like with window.scrollTo() on Chrome. (Perhaps I am completely wrong here.)

Read:

I really have no idea if this is a bug, a feature, some undocumented part of browser extensions, something browser specific, intended or whatever.

But:

At my side, window.scrollY can be set to something negative (which makes no sense at all) and hence the === becomes false.

This either is a Browser compatibility issue or some lack of documentation. In any way, it should be clearly stated.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
Chrome 102.0.5005.115 (Official Build) (64-bit)

item.title: [uievents] Document the ability to preventDefault() a pinch-zoom gesture on a touchpad
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/wheel_event

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

No response

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Firefox and Chrome (and maybe other browsers) allow websites to opt out of the browser's default handling of a touchpad pinch gesture (which is to zoom the page, either in a reflowing or a smooth/non-reflowing way depending on the browser version and touchpad hardware), by synthesizing a wheel event (with a modifier, usually Ctrl or Cmd depending on the platform) and giving the page a chance to preventDefault() the wheel event.

This is not very discoverable, since there isn't an obvious link between a pinch gesture and a wheel event.

(My understanding is, a wheel event was chosen for the following reasons:

  1. There isn't another event type in the web platform that would correspond more directly to a touchpad pinch gesture.
  2. Ctrl+wheel also causes zooming, and preventDefault()ing Ctrl+wheel was an existing way for sites to opt out of zooming, so it made sense to extend that to zooming caused by a touchpad gesture.)

What did you expect to see?

It would be nice to document this behaviour on MDN. Specifically, that:

  1. A touchpad pinch-zoom gesture results in the browser synthesizing a wheel event
  2. The zooming that's the browser's default behaviour in reponse to the gesture can be prevented using preventDefault() on that event

Not sure where the best place to document this is -- maybe the wheel event page? I'm open to suggestions.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

I implemented this behaviour in Firefox. Investigation of Chrome's similar behaviour is documented in bug 1619187. More recent testing suggests Safari now has the same behaviour as well.

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [encoding] "Buffer sizing" in `TextEncoder.encodeInto()` is English-centric
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/TextEncoder/encodeInto

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Buffer sizing

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The section says:

Note that the s.length * 3 is rare because the string would have to be packed with some of the few characters that expand into 3 bytes. It is unlikely that long text will exceed s.length * 2 bytes in length. Thus, a more optimistic approach might be to allocate s.length * 2 + 5 bytes, and perform reallocation in the rare circumstance that the optimistic prediction was wrong.

It may be true if the s is written in European languages, but in most case, to encode CJK strings needs s.length * 3 bytes because most of CJK characters are represented as three bytes per a character in UTF-8. So, it causes too frequent reallocation if s contains a string in CJK languages (which are used by about 20% people in the world).

What did you expect to see?

In the first place, should be such a section in a reference page? (I think it is preferred in guide pages).

If it is written in the page, it should just say that the max length needed for buffer is s.length * 3.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [cssom-1] [Web-API] Constructible stylesheets guide
item.content:encoded:
FF101 minimal release work for constructible stylesheets was done in #16411. This covered release notes and new properties.

What still need to be done is to provide an explanation of the API as "guide" material.
IN summary, it's a way to construct a CSS stylesheet programmatically so that it can be shared efficiently with shadow DOM subtrees.

This is mostly likely an addition to https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components/Using_shadow_DOM and lots of cross linking.

The main methods/properties are:

  • CSSStyleSheet methods including its CSSStyleSheet(), replace, replaceSync, insertRule, deleteRule and adoptedStylesheets in Document and ShadowRoot.

Resources

  • Explainer: https://github.com/WICG/construct-stylesheets/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md

  • Constructable Stylesheets (web.dev)

  • When done, mark this one dev-doc-complete https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1644102

item.content:encoded:

break-word is labelled as deprecated, with a note that overflow-wrap: anywhere is equivalent.
While this is true, overflow-wrap: anywhere; still isn't supported by safari, which isn't mentioned anywhere.

What did you expect to see?

I'm not sure exactly how to present this information, but I think the note about word-break: break-word being deprecated should mention:

  • word-break: break-word is deprecated in favor of overflow-wrap: anywhere
  • anywhere is not supported by all browsers, so word-break: break-word should be used instead
  • also consider overflow-wrap: break-word, which behaves similarly

(In my experience, to achieve reasonable text wrapping, you always want either overflow-wrap: anywhere (word-break: break-all) or overflow-wrap: break-word, depending on how you want the intrinsic size to be calculated, so this is a pretty important property to understand)

item.title: [css-conditional-3, DOM-Parsing] Defining page types
item.content:encoded:
Tracking issue for openwebdocs/project#91.

In this project we will aim to:

  • define a complete set of page types for all of MDN's pages
  • document the types in our meta-docs
  • add a front matter items to every page representing its type

The main aim of this is to define types for structured pages - that is, for pages that are always expected to conform to a particular organization. However, I think it will be helpful to have an explicit "guide" type for pages that aren't structured pages.

Scope

In the first part I'd like to understand the scope of this project. The output of this will be a collection of "doc sets" which we will analyze.

A doc set is a group of related pages on MDN - like the JS docs, or the Learn area, and so on.

I'm doing this in a spreadsheet, here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/14RX8EEKPpeYkP2cF5Y_ZKF3JpNJ_24OL7stvZWNJLIY/ .

In the "all doc sets" tab I've listed:

  • all top-level directories under MDN
  • all top-level directories under Web

Each of these, more or less, is a doc set.

I've then asked whether each doc set contains structured content. Doc sets that don't contain structured content are out of scope - they're all "guide" pages.

Then for each doc set that contains structured content I've assigned a priority 1-3. I think for now we should consider the P1 sets, which are:

  • API
  • CSS
  • HTML
  • HTTP
  • JavaScript
  • Learn

The pages in those doc sets are the pages that we will look at for this project.

I think we should execute the project in two phases:

  • defining the page types we want to have
  • adding the page types to the pages

I think we should do all of the analysis first: that is, we should define page types for all doc sets before we update any pages. That's because it is likely that we will end up changing our mind about some definitions as we analyze later doc sets.

Page type definition

So for the first phase we'll define page types for the following doc sets:

  • API: #16255
  • CSS: #15540
  • HTML: #22705
  • HTTP: #22761
  • JavaScript: #16156
  • Learn

Page type implementation

For the second phase we'll add the defined values to the pages.

item.title: [css-contain-2] Containing block via contain:paint vs other alternatives
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/MDN/Contribute/Feedback

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Layout and the containing block

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Regarding Layout and the containing block - CSS: Cascading Style Sheets | MDN,
the list Identifying the containing block includes this for item iv:
A contain value of paint (e.g. contain: paint;)

This is misleading since the "value of paint" is overly specific, suggesting the literal value "paint" is used, and the "(e.g. contain: paint;)" is then confusing because it would be redundant. The reader might be suspicious that there is more to the story, and there is!

What did you expect to see?

Instead of saying "value of paint", it should refer to "Paint containment" with the link to information about other ways to specify a paint containment. The link to contain is also useful since it is more direct, at least for this way of specifying a paint containment. On that page, we find

Note: If applied (with value: paint, strict or content), this property creates:

A new [containing block](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Containing_block) (for the descendants whose [position](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/position) property is absolute or fixed).

So, back to the containing block page, why not say "value of 'paint', 'strict', or 'content'", so people don't have to figure out that a value of 'content' (or 'strict'?) implies the equivalent of a value of 'paint'?

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

MDN documentation is a great service, all the more reason to keep it accurate while being very readable.

I'm not sure about all the other possible ways of affecting the containing block. This problem came up while trying to figure out why position:fixed was not doing what was expected. See Why is my fixed position element not relative to the viewport? - Darren Lester

Text says "If a record already exists in the object store with the key parameter as its key, then an error ConstrainError event is fired on the returned request object."

In fact, the example confusingly applies the "onerror" to the transaction, not the request object as stated (yea, I know it bubbles to the transaction, but the example is still confusing if that is not noted to the beginner)
If I could:
try { transaction.objectStore(store).add(foo); }
catch(e) { (e instanceof ConstraintError) ? ......... }
then I could move forward.
It's a lot of work to create a database, fill it, then try to create errors and probe results from there.

a complete reference to the method

item.title: [html, gamepad] Double checking the gamepad docs are correct
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL

/en-US/docs/Web/API/Gamepad_API/Using_the_Gamepad_API

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Multiple sections

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I could be reading the article wrong but ... stuff like this

Note: The Gamepad object is available on the gamepadconnected event rather than the Window object itself, for security reasons. Once we have a reference to it, we can query its properties for information about the current state of the gamepad. Behind the scenes, this object will be updated every time the gamepad's state changes.

What did you expect to see?

AFAIK This wrong.

#1. While it's true a gamepad object will be provided on gamepadconnected, it's also true that gamepad objects will be provided by navigator.getGamepads

#2. The description above and elsewhere suggests holding on to a reference to the gamepad object and querying it for values. But this fails. In fact, the example code in the article does not do this. It updates the gamepad objects near the end

       controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];

In other words, it's updating the controllers array with a new gamepad object for the same gamepad.

If instead you did this

   // no need to use a new gamepad object if we already have a gamepad object
   // for this controller from the gamepadconnected event
   if (!controllers[gamepads[i].index]) {
      controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];
   }

You'd see the example would fail. At least in Chrome I get a few readings and then gamepad object I was holding a reference too goes dead. Where as if I made sure to get new gamepad objects by calling navigator.getGamepads then the code keeps running.

Let me add, holding on to a reference used to work. I was grabbing some old code that held references and I know worked great when I wrote it 7 yrs ago but suddenly it was not working. I tracked the issue down to this. You can't keep a reference to the gamepad object. You need to take new ones by calling getGamepads

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

item.title: [hr-time-3, performance-timeline-2, resource-timing-2, user-timing-2] Topic on setting HTTP priority of resource requests
item.content:encoded:
When loading a page with many resources it can be useful to prioritize the requests so that the page appears to render more quickly. It would be useful to have a topic on this.

There are a bunch of ways to do this:

  • Use fetch() and set the priority in Request.priority.
  • Set the HTTP priority on HTMLLinkElement, HTMLIFrameElement, and HTMLImageElement elements (and associated tags) using the fetchpriority attribute.
  • In future maybe Priority HTTP header. There are also some ideas (from here), some of which may be relevant (e.g. marking the non-critical ones as async):
  • Mark non-critical scripts as async
  • Consider inlining @font-face declarations directly into HTML
  • Avoid using CSS background images or @import
  • Use preload to retrieve critical resources earlier

Possible locations for such a page are under these:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Performance
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch ?

This comes out of the discussion here: #14561

item.title: [css-fonts-5] Issue with "font-size": recommend to users not to set font-size with "em" units
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-size

A user in the MDN Web Docs Matrix room commented about how the mdn/css-examples repo defines its body font sizes with the em unit (that is, the interactive example at the top of the page).

Using em to define a font size isn't a good practice, because ems are based upon the font size -- in other words, this is setting a font size to...well, relative to the parent's font size. On the body, this isn't as big of an issue, but say you set font-size: 1.25em on something like div, which can have many children: now, each child div is going to have a font size of 125% relative to its parent's font size, creating a constantly-growing font size.

I think that the example shouldn't include an em as one of its default options, especially not as the first option. I also think that we should update the MDN page to include a note at the top to state as such and add a section to explain why.

I found a video that explains why to avoid ems as a font size, which I used as a reference for this.

item.title: [uievents] mouseleave is fired when the pointer has exited the element is inaccurate
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/mouseleave_event

Specific page section or heading?

Most of it, but particularly in the introduction: "...mouseleave is fired when the pointer has exited the element..."

What is the problem?

In fact, the mouseleave event fires on an IMG if the pointer enters an AREA defined in a MAP referenced by an IMG - even if that AREA is entirely within the image. In my mental model, an area is a part of an image; leaving it does not imply I have left the image. (Though both Chrome and Firefox behave as if it does imply leaving the image.)

What did you expect to see?

Well, an accurate description :-).

Perhaps a more thorough definition of "exit". A MAP seems to present a problem specific to an IMG element. Neither the map, nor its areas, seems to have a heirarchial relationship to the image, so it's not covered by the discussion of hierarchy.

Perhaps add somewhere "In the case of an image map, the cursor is considered to have left the image when it enters an area, even if that area is contained entirely within the image. Similarly, when the cursor exits an area but remains within the image, a mouseleave event on the area will fire, and a mouseenter event on the image will also fire."

I should probably go to W3 to see if someone addressed the issue...

Did you test this? If so, how?

Tediously.

I attached a single mouseenter handler, and a single mouseleave handler, to every IMG and AREA on a page. They log messages to the console. I'll guess that anyone reading this will immediately recognize what I have not understood, and the details are not necessary. I'm omitting them to reduce clutter, but will happily provide code and logs on request :-)

item.title: [web-animations-2, css-animations-2] Issue with "Element.animate()": wrong scenario mentioned
item.content:encoded:

and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Animations_API/Keyframe_Formats

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

In newer browser versions, you are able to set a beginning or end state for an animation only (i.e. a single keyframe), and the browser will infer the other end of the animation if it is able to.

This mentions two scenarios when only one keyframe is mentioned:

  1. from key frame is inferred. It's the elements current state. The corresponding code snippet covers this case.
  2. to key frame is inferred. In what scenario a browser will be able to infer the end frame given only one frame? Unlike CSS @keyframe rule there are no to and 100% keywords in DOM API. I don't think this scenario is possible. If it is possible, then please provide an example on the pages.
    I think the author is talking about following case:
let rotate360 = [
      { transform: 'rotate(360deg)' },
      {}   // empty keyframe, values are inferred from elements starting state
    ];

But in this case there are two keyframes provided.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/animate#implicit_tofrom_keyframes
and also
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Web_Animations_API/Keyframe_Formats#implicit_tofrom_keyframes

What did you expect to see?

Correct the description saying from frame is inferred if only one keyframe is provided.
Or provide an example for the second scenario.

item.title: [css-lists-3] Issue with "counter-reset": What is the difference in behavior between the latest Firefox (82 or later) and the older 81 or earlier or other browsers?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/counter-reset

Maybe the page to fix is this: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Counter_Styles/Using_CSS_counters

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

  • (p1) I know that starting with Firefox 82, the behavior of counter-reset has changed from 81 and earlier versions.
    • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1754521
  • (p2) For example, the results of the CSS Demo for counter-reset are different between Firefox (the latest version) and Google Chrome.
    • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/counter-reset
  • (p3) The ol and ul elements use CSS counter(list-item) to calculate the numbering in the marker.
    • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#propdef-list-style-type
  • (p4) I'd like to see a clear sample of the difference in behavior between counter-reset and counter-set.
  • (p5) In addition, I would like to see a more helpful example of how to use reversed().

It is my hope that the documentation will clearly explain why each browser behaves the way it does.

In particular, I think the following current statement is wrong.

The value to reset the counter to on each occurrence of the element. Defaults to 0 if not specified.

The latest version of Firefox doesn't seem to reset to on each occurrence of the element. This may just be because it resets the counter, but creates another instance, which makes it look like the counter is not being reset.

Related specs

  • https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#counter-reset
  • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#counter-reset
  • w3c/csswg-drafts#4244
  • w3c/csswg-drafts#5477
  • https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#lists
  • https://drafts.csswg.org/css-lists/#propdef-list-style-type

Related links

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1548753
  • #3737
  • #6360
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1754521
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1757269

What did you expect to see?

I don't know what the specs say about subtle nuances and what is the right way to behave.

item.title: [css-values-3] Content suggestion: Remove <length-percentage> and similar pages
item.content:encoded:
What is the new suggestion?

Remove https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/length-percentage and similar pages.

Why is it important or useful?

mdn/browser-compat-data#14971 is a PR to remove it in BCD, because support data is just the union of two other features. If we remove it from BCD, either the MDN page should be removed, or it includes the two compat tables for <length> and <percentage>.

Other supporting information

My weak opinion is that exposing these spec abstractions to readers is a bit weird, but that argument also applies to <length> and <percentage>. Perhaps they're useful to avoid spelling out all the allowed values for each property.

item.title: [permissions-policy-1] Permissions API - update to docs needed
item.content:encoded:
• Permissions API
  • Using the Permissions API

The Permission API is associated with UI features that require explicit permission from the user to access (or some equivalent proxy for permission). For example, geolocation potentially exposes very sensitive user information and hence requires explicit user permission to use. It is used by developers to determine whether permission has been granted to use the associated API.

There are a number of things to fix in the current MDN docs. The main one is that it is too easy to confuse with the Permissions API (related to user granted permissions) with the Permission Policy which provides server granted permissions to use similar features. Both APIs are similarly named and use similar/same strings to define the features.

  • We need to explicitly capture the main differences, as outlined in https://w3c.github.io/permissions/#relationship-to-permissions-policy . For example, UI vs server, the fact that if permission policy is not allowed, the permission API will always be denied.
  • Make sure that the difference is also captured in the Permission policy doc - ie. not just assume the existence of an overlap
  • Explain what the permission API permissions are - ie refer to a list.

The permissions API permissions are now defined in each spec, but registered in a powerful feature registry: https://w3c.github.io/powerful-features-registry/ we should explain that.

Other things:

  • The "Using" doc refers to quite old builds. General update would be good.

@marcoscaceres Love your work in w3c/permissions#263 . Would appreciate it if you are able to keep an eye on the MDN fixes. Not sure who will do them. Possibly me, once I finish my queue :-)

item.title: [cssom-view-1] Issue with "Document: scroll event": Example using rAF in scroll-event callbacks is outdated, and anti-performance
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/scroll_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The example using requestAnimationFrame in scroll event callbacks is totally outdated, it in fact anti-performance wise in these days.

Firing scroll events is aligned/defined in the HTML spec, all major browsers, Chrome, Safari and Firefox fire before processing requestAnimationFrame callbacks, so with the requestAnimationFrame callacks it just triggers queuing a redundant requestAnimationFrame callback and invoking the callback.

Specific section or headline?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/scroll_event#examples

What did you expect to see?

Scroll event handlers can be used without requestAnimationFrame callbacks.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested with a simple example having scroll event handler and requestAnimationFrame callbacks something like this;

window.addEventListener("scroll", e => {                                        
  console.log("got a scroll event on " + document.timeline.currentTime);        
});                                                                             
requestAnimationFrame(function rAF() {                                          
  console.log("got a rAF callback on " + document.timeline.currentTime);        
  requestAnimationFrame(rAF);                                                   
});

Thank you, MDN content editors.

item.title: [IndexedDB-3] Issue with "IDBTransaction.oncomplete": When transaction's oncomplete is actually called?
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/IDBTransaction/oncomplete

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It mentioned open a read/write transaction on our database and add SOME data to an object store but in example only shows single objectStore.add(). So it's still confusing when transaction's oncomplete is actually called since there is no transaction closing command anywhere.

Specific section or headline?

In Example part

What did you expect to see?

Show an example with multiple objectStore's operations to make it clear when oncomplete is actually called

Did you test this? If so, how?

No. It should be well documented.

item.title: [uievents] Content bug: Missing information about what WheelEvent.delta* can be
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaX
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaY
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaZ
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent/deltaMode

What is the problem?

Missing information described in w3c/uievents#181 (comment)
And the change in Firefox caused by Intent to ship: Return pixel deltas in wheel event if deltaMode is not checked by authors, that modify the behavior to the following, decided per event:

  • If deltaMode has been accessed, then the original delta mode and deltas are reported.

  • If deltaMode has not been accessed, and it's DOM_DELTA_LINE, accessing any of the deltas cause the event to always report DOM_DELTA_PIXELS, and the deltas get converted to pixels using the font-size of the target element.

For more information see:

  • w3c/uievents#181
  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1392460

item.title: [css-display-3] Issue with "display": table accessibility concern should specify browsers
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/display#tables

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Changing the display value of a table element can alter its representation in an accessibility tree, but Firefox ESR and Chrome stable don't appear to have that issue. Gnome Web 41.0 does have this issue, so this is still a valid accessibility concern.

Specific section or headline?

In Accessibility concerns under Tables it states:

Changing the display value of a <table> element to block, grid, or flex will alter its representation in the accessibility tree.

(Emphasis added and hyperlinks removed)

What did you expect to see?

Some browsers alter there accessibility tree based on display: table.

Given this is a browser based issue, adding a related entry to the Browser Compatibility table might also be ideal.

Did you test this? If so, how?

  1. Open the following HTML in any browser I want to test: 
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en-us">
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
    <title>Display Grid Table</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <table style="grid">
      <caption>Grid Table</caption>
      <tbody>
        <tr>
          <th>Hello</th>
          <td>World</td>
        </tr>
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </body>
</html>
  2. Use browser accessibility tools to check the role of each table node to see if they have changed
    • Usually roles just get erased entirely if changed
  • Firefox ESR (Debian Buster) or Chrome OS 94.0 show no changes in the accessibility tree roles
  • Gnome Web 41.0 will remove all table roles from table elements rooted with a non-table display value
    • Making tbody display grid removes table roles from it and its children, but not its parents

item.title: [css-fonts-5] Issue with "@font-face/font-weight": Document <font-weight-absolute>{2}
item.content:encoded:

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

There should be more ample space devoted to font-weight ranges (<font-weight-absolute>{2}) required for variable fonts to work reliably across browsers.

I've only just started writing my first variable font CSS today, off the cuff, so I don't have an insight on the history of the spec / known browser quirks, but pretty soon I discovered that not mentioning a font-weight range in @font-face causes issues in Chrome and Safari.

In particular, the example in the Variable fonts section of the more famous font-weight CSS property of the two currently doesn't work in Chrome due to this omission. I have opened a PR on the css-examples repo to address it:

  • mdn/css-examples#56

What did you expect to see?

The expansion of the "Variable fonts" section with a note about the importance of adding a font-weight range, and ideally an sample @font-face declaration for variable fonts in the Examples section.

Tested before/after code in the aforementioned PR in Chrome.

item.title: [css-transforms-2, css-transforms-1] Issue with "transform": Need to clarify transform-function application in reverse order
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/transform

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It's not obvious or clear that the transform functions are effectively applied in reverse order, and that each represents a transform matrix applied to the initial vector of each of the four corners of the target.

In vector/matrix maths we write V(result) = M(1) M(2) V(initial). The assumed operator is 'matrix multiplication'. Thus we see that M(2) is applied first. A link to something explaining this would be useful.

If perspective() is one of multiple function values, it must be listed first.

Really? Surely it's just another matrix.

Specific section or headline?

n/a

What did you expect to see?

Some explanation of the maths, at least indicating that the transforms are applied in reverse order.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I studied mathematics at university.

item.title: [mediaqueries-4, css-conditional-3] Issue with "@media": Need more clarity re Level 4 v Level 3, browser compat, and broken links
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@media

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The link to the W3C CSS Level 3 spec is broken.

The link to your own CSS Level 3 archive (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Archive/CSS3) is also broken.

I think there needs to be more clarity on the page on the differences between Level 3 and Level 4, particularly regarding the not and or operators, and more particularly because AFAIK Firefox is the only browser that supports Level 4 here.

I think there should be more examples using the not and or operators for both Level 3 and Level 4. I have not come across the or operator before (in Level 3 one would use the comma operator).

The browser compatibility table should include whether Level 4 is supported for @media rules.

The browser compatibility table should include which media features are supported (not all support all). Some browsers will discard entire @media rules if they include an unsupported media feature.

Specific section or headline?

Various sections.

What did you expect to see?

Clearer guidance for developers.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yes, multifariously. And from experience.

item.title: [service-workers-1] Issue with "ServiceWorkerContainer.register()": Second example unclear on intent
item.content:encoded:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ServiceWorkerContainer/register

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Specific section or headline?

Alternatively, if this code were included in a page at example.com/product/description.html, with the Javascript file residing at example.com/product/sw.js, then the service worker would only apply to resources under example.com/product.

if ('serviceWorker' in navigator) {
// declaring scope manually
navigator.serviceWorker.register('/sw.js', {scope: './'}).then(function(registration) {

What did you expect to see?

The text talks about sw.js residing in example.com/product/sw.js, however example uses /sw.js which is It is relative to the base URL of the application, meaning in this case example.com/sw.js.

So either the text or the example is wrong, maybe something like this would be more clear / correct?

Alternatively, if this code were included in a page at example.com/product/description.html, with the Javascript file residing at example.com/sw.js, then the following example shows how to limit scope to example.com/product by using relative scope.

if ('serviceWorker' in navigator) {
// declaring scope manually, relative to current URI scope
navigator.serviceWorker.register('/sw.js', {scope: './'}).then(function(registration) {

The Using DTMF page in the WebRTC docs is using the offerToReceiveAudio and offerToReceiveVideo options, which in the RTCPeerConnection.createOffer() docs are described as "legacy":

item.title: [ecmascript, FileAPI] Clean up irrelevant notes about old browser releases
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileReader/error says:

In Chrome 48+/Firefox 58+ this property returns a DOMException because DOMError has been removed from the DOM standard.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/typeof#regular_expressions says:

typeof /s/ === 'function'; // Chrome 1-12 Non-conform to ECMAScript 5.1
typeof /s/ === 'object';   // Firefox 5+  Conform to ECMAScript 5.1

What is the problem?

Information about quirks in very old browser releases seems like a net negative for readers of MDN. It will require readers to make a judgement about whether this could affect them, by testing or looking at release dates for the browsers.

What did you expect to see?

Irrelevant information should be pruned from MDN after some time. Perhaps some special markup could be used when referring to a specific browser version, so that tools could be written to list information about browser releases too old to be relevant. Such cleanup happens to some extent in BCD, around irrelevant features removed from all browsers for more than 2 years, and also old flag data.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Searching for "Chrome " + a number of any other browser followed by a number can find many examples like these.

item.title: [service-workers-1, payment-request, payment-handler] Content bug: inconsistent/incomplete descriptions of Promises as parameters
item.content:encoded:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

Compare the descriptions of parameters here:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PaymentRequest/show
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PaymentRequestUpdateEvent/updateWith

What is the problem?

PaymentRequest's show() method is documented as taking a promise, while PaymentRequestUpdateEvent's updateWith() method is documented as taking an object. Actually, the two both accept the same kind of parameter, and because of the way that promises work, one can pass either an object directly or a promise that resolves to an object.

What did you expect to see?

A consistent style that makes it clear what can be used as the argument.

Promises as parameters is not very common on the web platform, but there are other cases that also have a mix of styles:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PaymentRequestEvent/respondWith (also incorrectly says the PaymentResponse interface instead of the PaymentHandlerResponse dictionary)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ExtendableEvent/waitUntil (no issue here because the promise can resolve to anything)
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FetchEvent/respondWith (correctly says "Response or a Promise that resolves to a Response")
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/WebAssembly/compileStreaming (correctly says "Response object or a promise that will fulfill with one")

item.title: [uievents] Issue with "Element: keydown event": What generates a KeyboardEvent?

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/keydown_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Keyboard events are only generated by <inputs>, <textarea> and anything with the contentEditable attribute or with tabindex="-1".

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

They seem to be generated by arbitrary focusable elements. I expected something like:

Keyboard events are only generated by focusable elements. This includes <button>, <a>, <input>, <textarea>, and anything with the contenteditable or tabindex attributes.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I added listeners for the keydown and keyup events to an <a>, a <button> and a <span> with tabindex=0, and then when I typed while the elements were focused, the listeners got called.

I should also add that the listeners for these events that were attached to parents of the focusable elements also got called (I'm guessing this is because the event bubbles up).
